Award.AwardTitle: Interfacial induced Properties in GaN devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to develop memory devices and magnetic tunnel junctions, based on controlling the magnetic state of dilute magnetic III-Nitride semiconductors. These device structures will show that manipulation of spin states is feasible in dilute magnetic GaN. The success of this program will be a step towards the realization of non-volatile memory in dilute magnetic GaN.
Intellectual Merit: The program will utilize controlling magnetism at hetero-structure interfaces to build memory devices and magnetic sensors that manipulate the spin states by an external electric field. The research project will focus on meeting the following goals: i) Establish correlations between mediated carriers and the ferromagnetic properties in magnetically doped GaN. ii) Demonstrate electric field control of ferromagnetism in memory cells. iii) Demonstrate magnetic sensors based on the magneto-resistance properties of magnetic-GaN/p-GaN layered structures.
Broader impacts: Coupling semiconductor devices with spin-electronic applications has the potential for room temperature nitride-based magnetic devices. The structures considered are transformative by the realization of room-temperature non-volatile memory and sensor devices based on III-nitrides. For educational outreach, a study group will work with the School of science on the NCSU Centennial Campus to make exciting new electro-magnetic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For more than a decade there has been considerable interest in dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) for potential spintronic applications, but their adoption has been inhibited by Curie temperatures that are significantly below 300K. The goal of this project was to demonstrate ferromagnetic (FM) behavior in p-i-n GaCrN-based device structures in which the saturation magnetization is enhanced via hole carrier mediation and by carrier injection in the p-i-n structure. These results would then enable development of a memory device that manipulates the spin states via an applied external electric field. This project demonstrated interfacial induced magnetism in transition metal-doped GaN for memory devices. The primary advantage of transition metal doped GaN is a Curie temperatures above 300K, which is required for spin-based memory devices and other novel spintronic applications.

The goal of this project was to control magnetic behavior at heterointerfaces to fabricate non-volatile memory devices with a low refresh rate and magnetic sensors. We have demonstrated hole mediated ferromagnetic behavior in GaCrN-based (p-i-n) device structures and achieved electric field control of ferromagnetism. Figure 1 demonstrates modulation of the magnetic moment via an applied bias. These results are significant for the development of transition metal-doped GaN-based structures for memory devices. The voltage control of ferromagnetism may have significant impact on spintronics by enabling integration of ferromagnetic and non-magnetic semiconductors.
